x4freetext: Details of capture yield calibration method.
GELINA at IRMM
Electrons generate bremsstrahlung in rotating U
target - neutrons were mainly produced by gamma,n and
gamma,f reactions.
Isotopically enriched metallic tungsten disks were part
of the inventory of the ORNL isotope program.
For each isotope identical metallic disks were used and
combined in the experiment to obtain different sample
thickness.
Isotope       Label   Weight     Diameter   Thickness
(g)        (cm)       (cm)
Different flight path lengths and repetition
rates.
Transmission measurement.
-1ns pulse width with a repetition rate of 800Hz.
Neutron beam was collimated to a 4.5cm diameter at
the sample position. Background as a function of TOF
can be derived by the `black resonance` technique.
- Shorter flight path of 25m with a 50Hz repetition
rate - at low neutron energy part.
Capture measurement.
-30m (flight path 15) and 60m (flight path 14), GELINA
operating at 800Hz.
Additional runs using a sample holder, an aluminum
canning dummy and Pb-208 sample in the beam in order to
determine the background originating from the sample
holder and the scattered neutrons.Black resonance
filters were placed in the beam for supplementary
background control and B10 slab served as frame overlap
filter.
-In a third set of experiments the samples were
positioned at flight path 5, at a distance of 10m from
the neutron production target. Repetition rate of 50Hz
focusing on the thermal energy range of the neutron
spectrum.
-To normalize the capture yield the data obtained for
flight paths 14 and 15, several runs having natural
iron samples in the neutron beam were performed. The
1.15keV resonance in Fe-56 was used for normalization.
Additional runs with natural iron and tungsten disks
were performed. Silver samples were used for the 50Hz
runs at flight path 5 and the normalization factor was
deduced after applying the saturated resonance
technique.
At 50m measuring station,neutrons were detected
by 0.635-cm-thick Li-6-loaded glass scintillator,viewed
by one photomultiplier placed outside of the neutron
beam, at a distance of 49.33m .
In the first case two C6D6 detectors,
for the longer distance four C6D6 are used to detect
the capture gamma rays.
At 80cm prior the detectors` array a B-10 loaded
ionization chamber served as a flux monitor.
The software code AGS (Analysis of Geel Spectra,
C. Bastian et al.. AGS, Computer Code for Uncertainty
Propagation in time of flight Cross Section Data,
Physor 2006, Vancouver, Canada,2006) was used to reduce
the data.
Request of data sent 2011-07-22 to C.Lampoudis
Christos.Lampoudis@ec.europa.eu - reply 24 Aug 2011:
"The data will be available only after been fully
analyzed."
